Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Potable water hazards and resource needs in private well communities impacted by extreme flooding events

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Texans are starting to recover and rebuild from Hurricane Harvey, which caused record-setting flooding and widespread destruction. While efforts are underway to restore drinking water supplies and notify residents of potential contamination concerns, a significant percentage of the impacted population in Texas has complete responsibility for ensuring the safety and integrity of their own water supplies coming from private wells. Safe drinking water regulations do not apply to residential private wells in the United States. After the Great Louisiana Flood of 2016, the investigators' team learned that that even six weeks after the height of the flood, 20% of wells still tested positive for total coliform bacteria, and DNA markers for opportunistic pathogens were detected in 75% of wells for Legionella spp., 15% for L. pneumophila, and 20% for the brain-eating amoeba Naegleria fowerli. Such public health risks associated with flood-impacted wells have been widely unaddressed. Standardized communication and remediation strategies for private wells affected by natural disasters are urgently needed. Through this RAPID grant, the research team will collect microbial water quality data, and characterize resources and informational needs as residents in Texas (and Florida, following Hurricane Irma) return home and begin to use their private wells.

This RAPID grant will help assist the private well owners impacted by Hurricane Harvey (Texas) and Hurricane Irma (Florida) in assessing and addressing the current safety of their potable water supply. Results from this research will inform whether one-time disinfection protocols should be recommended to private well residents for recovery, and also provide insight to impediments to disaster recovery when considering the microbial contamination encountered after severe flooding events. Results will aid the development of guidelines for government and public health officials, emergency responders, and private well owners, on well water hazards after floods and the resource needs of well owners. More effective intervention strategies will help well owners to protect themselves and their families from flood-associated hazards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research evaluated well water quality and resource needs in well communities impacted by Hurricane Harvey (Texas) and Irma (Florida). In addition, with data collected in the aftermath of the 2016 flood in Louisiana, we provide a comprehensive multi-state characterization of flood-impacted microbial health risks of private wells, with emphasis on documenting the presence of opportunistic pathogens in private wells. Lastly, we examined shock chlorination to determine if this one-time disinfection protocol can reduce waterborne disease.

 

Evaluation of water quality and recovery needs after flooding

To understand the magnitude of flooding impact of the well community, we estimated the number of private wells potentially flood during Hurricane Harvey and compared this to the number of private wells sampled. According to USGS data, 8.3 million residents were residing in counties that declared a federal disaster area. While most (95.1%) were supplied by municipal drinking water service, an estimated 308,949 well users were potentially impacted (an estimated 77,237-154,475 private wells). Between the three primary organizations assisting well users during Hurricane Harvey recovery, 8,822 well water samples were analyzed for coliform bacteria. Thus, 5.7-11.4% of impacted wells were tested after Hurricane Harvey, illustrating the magnitude of effort required to assist all impacted well users.

Our sampling efforts revealed that 29.6% samples (n=8,822) were positive for total coliform and 11.0% (n=3,887) were positive for E. coli. However, there are no baseline coliform bacteria well water data for Texas, so accurately determining the change in incidence was not possible. Using prior well water testing data during non-flooding conditions, total coliform rates did not appear higher than prior rates but E. coli was almost three times higher. This is not surprising as roughly two thirds of participants reported flooding in the homes and around their wellheads. In addition, well system damage was reported by 20% of participants, with most reporting electrical problems with pumps and broken pipes.

 

Multi-state evaluation of opportunistic pathogens (OPs)

A total of 139 samples were collected from private wells in Texas (n=61), Florida (n=40), and Louisiana (n=38) following flooding caused by Hurricane Harvey in 2017, Hurricane Irma in 2017, and the Great Louisiana Flood in 2016. Legionella spp. were the most commonly detected OP genus. Overall, 76 of 139 samples (54.7%) were positive for Legionella spp., with quantifiable samples ranging from 8.17 to 1.62?104 gene copies/mL. L. pneumophila, the most commonly reported pathogenic species of the genus Legionella, was detected in 18 of the 76 samples (23.7%) that were positive for Legionella spp. and 12.9% of all samples. Samples with quantifiable L. pneumophila ranged from 6.19 to 1.08?102 gene copies/mL. Mycobacterium spp. was the next most frequently detected (43 of 139 samples, 30.9%). Samples with quantifiable Mycobacterium spp. ranged from 13.3 to 3.03?103 gene copies/mL. M. avium, the most common cause of MAC infections in immunocompromised individuals, was detected in 27 of the 43 samples (62.8%) positive for Mycobacterium spp. and 19.4% of all samples. However, all M. avium samples were all below quantification limit. The incidence of N. fowleri was low, with detection in only 12 of 139 samples (8.6%). Two samples had quantifiable levels of N. fowleri at 20.1 and 2.51?102 gc/mL. Overall, there was no difference in the detection of these pathogens by state

 

Shock chlorination workshop for residents

With the presence of microbial contamination, user-friendly remediation strategies are imperative. To evaluate if residents can perform shock chlorination, we hosted an educational training class. A total of 138 participants attended the class at the four county locations, and 62 participants filled out at least one survey. Reported knowledge of locating well water treatment and testing resources was observed to be higher post-class (92.0%). However, participants? ability to calculate a chlorine dose for well disinfection was problematic. Prior to the class, only 2 participants (5.4%) answered this question correctly. After the class, 45.9% of participants correctly answered the question, 45.9% incorrectly answered, and 8.1% marked ?don?t know?. Participants were reported to be significantly more comfortable independently disinfecting their well water after the class. Overall, participants agreed they would recommend the class to others, as the class covered their respective information needs.

 

Overall, this research continued to advance the understanding of the impact of flooding on private well communities and well recovery. Educational and professional development opportunities were provided to 6 graduate students and 3 postdoctoral researchers at three universities. This collaborative research also fostered collaborative research projects with multiple Cooperative Extension and state government agencies and provided testing and educational platforms and resources for residents. Research from this grant will result in 6 journal article submissions and has contributed to two graduate theses.
